2019 EDIT: Change of rating. 'Jellicoe Road' is another book I look back on with not much fondness, and I am no longer comfortable with it being on my bookshelf. Maybe I think it's pretentious, overly contrived and melodramatic (ironic, since there isn't much of a plot to speak of, or remember, and why you should care.) Melodramatic yet detached from the characters' emotions and situations. Cynical yet silly, now there's a paradox. The book is not even magical realism, but it reads like it. Like, the main character is psychic, and has prophetic dreams? And dreams of what happened when she was little more than a baby, and before she was born - dreams of meeting people who died before she was born, but she knows them so well - what? Add in the fact that, for her seemingly perfect memory, even of traumatic events, she has repressed memories of things that are convenient for the book's weak mystery "plot" to work.I'll never forgive the line of dialogue about Anne Frank: "The girl never kept her mouth shut, she was bloody annoying." THIS IS SAID ABOUT A HOLOCAUST VICTIM. A FOURTEEN-YEAR-OLD HOLOCAUST VICTIM. Even though it's said by a teenage boy, he isn't called out on it. It's sexist, and in incredible bad taste. It's vile. Most of the characters are unlikable, and all of the adults, as I've said before, are crap, even for YA.So, unable to defend it now, and in spite of its popularity and high praise, I wipe my hands clean of 'Jellicoe Road' for good. Perhaps it's overrated, not that great, or it hasn't aged well. The same could be said for most if not all of Melina Marchetta's YA novels.Original review:Right. Here goes nothing:'Jellicoe Road' has soooo much hype surrounding it, and for good reason. Even though I'd read a lot of positive Goodreads reviews before picking it up and reading, I kept my expectations fairly low. It still surprised me.'Jellicoe Road' is a fantastic and fascinating novel, full of memorable and distinctive characters and scenes - an enriching mixture that just makes you choke up. Like with nearly all books by Melina Marchetta, it has quotable passages and lines of dialogue on almost every page, and they're poignant and beautiful. How Ms Marchetta comes up with all of these life philosophies, I don't know. And it amazes me. I think I love the setting the most, which is a boarding school in the woods, like a summer camp only secretly full of brutal teens fighting and kidnapping each other for territory purposes. And there's a "Prayer Tree". Treehouses are adorable!It is certainly not your typical YA romance story either. There's much more depth to it than that.However... It's not perfect. I'll try listing the things I didn't like about this novel:1. The adults are crap. Really, there's no other word to describe them. Yes, I understand why they're crap - tragic childhood and never learning to grow up emotionally - but the decisions they make don't make sense to me. I won't reveal what those decisions are due to spoilers, but it has something to do with a pet-peeve I have about adult guardians keeping important secrets from their kids for no good reason. Emotional scarring or not, if you love and trust your children then they have a right to know the truth. Knowing nothing will most likely hurt and confuse them more than knowing something. The secret-keeping is there to add mystery to the plot, but most of the mysteries are rather obvious anyway and I found them to be a little too contrived, even with the emotional backing.2. Some characters had to grow on me long into the story before I could like them, such as Jonas Griggs and Taylor, believe it or not. But I liked characters such as little Jessa, Raffy and the tragedy-stricken but playful kids in flashbacks. Taylor I found to be too aggressive and selfish from the first chapter, but once I grasped her takes-no-shit ways (and she truly doesn't take any shit), and her unconscious desperation to know who she is and why her mother abandoned her on Jellicoe Road, I found her hard not to love and respect as a protagonist. Her life sucks, and she adapts to it by the only means she knows how (especially with irresponsible and thoughtless adults around making it worse).3. Santangelo's comment about Anne Frank on page 216 of my copy: "The girl never kept her mouth shut, she was bloody annoying." (I wonder if he'd say that if Anne Frank had been a boy. I doubt it.) But I'm sure this is somehow a compliment in context to the conversation he's having with Taylor and the Jellicoe gang, as he then says, "it was like nothing could kill what was inside of her". The character interactions in this book feel realistic and help shape the setting, by the way.4. The ending, while dramatic, is contrived. It is a pay-off of sorts to something only mentioned a few times throughout the book, and it didn't quite work for me. But it didn't turn out too badly. Because the next, not-so-theatrical pay-off - and climax - is a heart-wrenching conclusion to Taylor's story about self-discovery and what it means to have people around who love her.I could talk more about of the contrivances in the story, whether or not they are spoilery. However I do not want to put anybody off reading this novel, despite a few minor issues I had with it that made me give it 4 stars instead of 5.And I do feel bad about not giving 'Jellicoe Road' 5 stars, because it did have a profound effect on me emotionally and mentally, and Ms Marchetta is a genius. I guess the number of things that annoyed me were one too many.But I do really, really like it. It's a beautiful, wondrous story about maturity, family, friendship, the importance of memories and childhood, and the strength to change. It's a puzzle of a coming-of-age tale about one unique teen, Taylor Markham. The other characters and their lives are also unique, and add substance to the plot and the way it's structured. Imperfect people make up the heart of the story of 'Jellicoe Road', melodramatic or no.'Jellicoe Road' is one of those books that leaves you feeling so much that you don't know what to do after finishing it. It is tender-hearted despite its dark themes, and it is as funny as it is sad and shocking. Ms Marchetta has a gift of making you emotional from reading her writing, regardless of the premise or content. It may not be my number one favourite book of hers (which is still 'Finnikin of the Rock') - like it is for so many other readers - but there is definitely something special in this. I overall enjoyed the journey on the Jellicoe Road.Final Score: 4/5

3.5/5 StarsWhile it's true that Melina Marchetta is my queen for writing what is arguably one of the best trilogies of all time, The Lumatere Chronicles, I was left wanting upon finishing her renowned YA Contemporary hit, Jellicoe Road.Don't misunderstand me: it's not that it's written badly or that it doesn't evoke emotion or because it isn't a good story, but because it's not the easiest book to navigate. The premise of this story isn't established as effectively as it could have been. There's a good chunk of the book in which very little is explained, or is not explained well.For me, this book's biggest downfall is that, while the events of the story make dramatic sense in building the plot up to the climax and all of that, they weren't necessarily "full-proof." What I mean by that is that this story has a lot of potential for plotholes. Many things are left unsaid, and many things the reader may believe he or she understands are disregarded often.The main character, Taylor, was (obviously) the most well-written character of the bunch, and I sympathized with her struggle to understand where she belonged and why her mother abandoned her. She was what pulled me through the story, because I wanted to go on this emotional journey with her and understand her life alongside her. However, many of the side characters fell flat for the sake of that journey, I felt. I didn't understand the basis for her relationship with Jonah Griggs, and I was left unmoved by their consequent romance (which felt a tad rushed, despite having some backstory). Rather, earning about Taylor's past, and the way it's revealed bit by bit, is what makes this book memorable, not necessarily the characters themselves or their friendships. This is almost a book that you need to read twice to fully appreciate. And while I can respect that, and while I'm in awe of how the second half wholly changes the story entirely, knowing that this book practically demands two readings makes me feel a bit cheated as a reader. Had the premise(s) been better established, I think that readers would be able to get the full potential of this book with just one read-through.That being said, I really adored the latter half of this book. Melina Marchetta wrote with emotion and clear purpose, and I think it paid off in the end. I did enjoy following Taylor's story, and the way all the puzzle pieces fit together and how everything unfolded is something that I won't soon forget. Even though some aspects of this story could've been crafted better, I still really liked this book by the end and I eagerly look forward to reading more of Marchetta's contemporary work.

I have been wanting to read Jellicoe Road for years, and I was told it was best experienced without knowing anything about it. I was later told that it took half the book to really hook the reader, and that it ended up being worth it.It's...kind of worth it? I...I guess?The book has an arresting first sentence and intriguing prologue that describes a car accident...and then it moves forward twenty-two years to a teenage girl named Taylor who was not in the prologue, and she's in a weird school in Australia, and there are territory wars between Cadets and Townies, and I don't know what the fuck is going on.We get more flashes of the characters in the prologue. How are they connected to the present-day action? WHO KNOWS.Taylor is a perfectly likable character, but she definitely does not care whether the reader understands what's going on, especially because she doesn't know some of it. She makes references to various events in her past, but her own past is mysterious to her. She has weird dreams about a boy in a tree, she doesn't know her mother or father, she...there is just a lot of mystery here.The problem is that I was given almost no grounding to care about anyone or anything beyond wanting to know what was going on. The territory wars baffled me, making me think this was a dystopian, post-apocalyptic world (spoilers, it's not), and I couldn't connect to most of the characters.Halfway through the book—and I mean almost literally at the 50% mark—information is revealed that helped me recontextualize the narrative and understand what was going on. As Taylor discovers more about her past, I was certainly more engaged, but even then, Melina Marchetta's writing style may not be my thing, as dramatic revelations sometimes went uncommented on, and I still didn't really care so much about the characters. I had a lot of questions about the setup, about why characters acted a certain way and didn't tell people certain things. I liked elements of the ending, though.I should like this book more than I do. I admire the narrative structure, but it does ask a lot of the reader. It's an incredibly frustrating read for half the book, and while I enjoyed the various reveals, they don't quite make up for the first half. This is a book that is clearly better on the reread, but I don't have time for that.For the patient reader, Jellicoe Road can be a rewarding challenge, a story about family and friendship. For others, it may simply be a maddening tale with a decent payoff.

3.5/5.0 stars

But I remember you that day and you looked at peace with yourself and it made me reconsider everything I had planned to do. I don't think leaving me on that platform would have changed my life, Griggs," I lie."You being on that platform changed mine.” 
On the Jellicoe Road is not your typical young adult fiction, especially in terms of the story telling. That said, this novel may not be for everyone. The beginning was confusing although I don't doubt that the intention was to build up the mystery. But I'm the type of reader who likes a good old solid start to get me thoroughly invested, and sadly, my interest waned by the time the story came together.Melina Marchetta is actually one of my favorite authors, she excels both in YA fiction and fantasy and I find her writing style very clever and her characters are always interesting so I very rarely dislike her work. I did not hate this one but the characters didn't stick with me and in my case, that's a deal breaker. There was one scene though in this story that stuck with me, it came as a shock even. First I have to confess, I'm a little slow on predicting the big reveal most of the time, embarrassingly enough. And one of the major revelations in this book involves a train, that's all I'm going to say.

Before I start with my review, I just want to let you know that it is difficult for me to enjoy books under genre of “Realistic Fiction” or “Melodrama”. It’s just not my cup of tea although I do read books from these genre occasionally. What can I say about Jellicoe Road? It is a story of friendship, love and hope. It is a good and inspiring story. And quite engaging too especially at the second half of the book. I love the friendship from the two generations depicted in the story. In fact, I envy that kind of friendship. I longed for someone who will stick with you through thick and thin. A friendship that you know will last forever - no matter what happens. The first half of the book is confusing and frustrating. The story building doesn’t make any sense; it was slow and Taylor was annoying. It was boring and I almost DNFed it. At this point, I advise you not to. Just hold on to it because everything will be explained as the story progresses. The romance is sweet and true. I like the chemistry of Taylor and Jonah; Raffy and Chaz. I can’t help but smile when they’re together. The rest of the cast are quite good too. Raffy and Ben are so funny especially when they were teasing Taylor and Jonah. I think this is the point when I started enjoying this book. The funny bits and romantic scene kept me going until the end. The mystery about Taylor’s past is intriguing but predictable. I already know what will happen next and the huge issue from the past. The drama is just too cliche and I’ve seen this a lot in Pinoy drama series. It’s a sad, tragic story but it didn’t make me cry. Will I recommend it? Yes, if you like drama and something realistic.

I don't get the hype, really. I didn't find the characters compelling or interesting. To be totally honest, I thought it was quite predictable. Although I clearly didn't figure out *everything* at the end, I knew from page 5 that the characters in the manuscript were somehow the ones acting in Taylor's history. So, that said, no shock.I thought that there was no reason to care about Taylor. We know little about her for 300 pages, except that she's got mommy fixation. Even in the end, I still didn't care about Taylor nor understand why I should care about her. I felt like the last 100 pages were the best in the book in terms of writing, action, and story. I wish a lot at the start could have been cut OR could have been better fleshed out in terms of character development. I think there were too many characters without any defining features who just became names to me. All of that said, I think this book definitely would have its readers. I think a lot of reluctant readers would have a hard time with this one because it requires reading the whole book. I think it might even require two readings. In terms of writing, Marchetta can paint some nice images for sure. She can also paint quite brutal ones. Sensitive readers might be put off by this one, since it's quite brutal in parts. Alas, the book earns a 3 star because I might, in the future, reread it to see if I missed something. If a book I don't care for a whole lot can compel me to consider rereading, then maybe something's there. I'm not quite sure why this one, out of many other great contenders, achieved the Prinz. But, I'm also not on the committee :)

The Beginning: My father took one hundred and thirty-two minutes to die.Taylor Makham is abandoned by her mother at the age of 11 and goes to live on a boarding school. When she’s 17, her ‘substitute mother’ disappears. Taylor goes on a quest to find the missing adults in her life. At the same time, she has to lead an underground war against her biggest enemy – who she has a crush on.I had been warned that Jellicoe Road was confusing at first, but would then be extremely good once you figure things out. I guess I had expected more after this description. It just wasn’t my cup of tea, though. I liked reading about Taylor and how she would gradually put the pieces of the missing-parents-puzzle together. And the love story was very sweet and touching.I crave someone knowing me so well that they can tell what I’m thinking.But the territorial war in the underground community seemed downright silly to me. I wanted to scream ‘GET A LIFE’ at these kids. And this took up a huge part of the book. I understand why this book is appealing to some. It’s not bad at all, it just wasn’t for me.Here’s my favorite quote:According to Dickens, the first rule of human nature is self-preservation and when I forgive him for writing a character as pathetic as Oliver Twist, I’ll thank him for the advice.My blog: The Bookworm's Closet

Beware spoilers ahead.Well, hmm. There were parts of this book I found just wonderful -- in particular, Melina Marchetta does teenagers shooting the breeze and falling in love, the multiple layers of that dialogue and how it can be both understatedly casual and completely overwhelmingly meaningful and intense at the same time, better than anyone I know. I loved Taylor's relationship with Griggs, I loved the territory wars (once I figured out they were just a game and not some postapocalyptic serious thing), all the school stuff was great. But the family piece felt willfully obscure to me, and also sort of willfully irrational or melodramatic. Like, WHY wouldn't Hannah tell Taylor she was her aunt? She could do that without undermining her relationship with her mother, it seemed to me -- indeed, it might even clarify the Hannah-Taylor relationship by better defining the roles. Or why wouldn't she tell Taylor about her dad, her beloved brother? Did Taylor not know her mom's first name was Tate? The Hermit was Fitz, and he shot himself because he felt guilty about shooting Webb, right? And he did it in front of Taylor because she reminded him so much of Webb?Everyone says this is better the second time through, and I can believe that, and I guess I should go back and reread it. But the first read left me so nonplussed about all this that I don't really want to spend the eye time on the second read. It was okay, but I didn't love it.

It’s Marchetta writing contemporary young adult, and I didn’t totally love it, I know, I know. I found this book a little airy, a little insubstantial. I could see the gossamer filaments of the story float past me and not snag. But I think I learned something important about Marchetta and what she does. Her books lift me out of my life in this sincere, from the heart and the old, old memories way. They draw me out of myself and make me feel. But when I read this, I was already there. I was living in sleepless, striving, soul-searching intensity, trying really hard to listen to myself and someone else, and make us meet somewhere in the middle. So this book and I passed each other going the wrong direction, I guess.And you know, I think it’s actually really cool that I don’t love every Marchetta. My extremely unscientific analysis suggests that there are wide disparities in the books of hers people love. I mean, they’re all pretty good, but the special one is different for all my friends. Which says something good about her, that she’s tapping into something so deep, so personal, but so different every time.

This is a Printz that I actually didn't hate with a burning passion - impressive. I liked the idea for this story, but at times I felt it was a little random, and I wasn't sure how things were going to add up at the end. The beginning was really weird and I was trying to adjust to how the story was moving along and keep track of all the characters. The backstory that was interwoven throughout was really intriguing and I kept reading because I wanted to know what had happened. The ending was unsuspecting, but still fulfilling. I wouldn't recommend this book to everyone because some of the content was objectionable and it wasn't as fast moving of a story as I would have liked. It had potential though, it just needed a little bit more tweaking to have made it a really good read.*Taken from my book reviews blog: http://reviewsatmse.blogspot.com/2009...

I liked the writing. The story was interesting. I got tired of the "f" word used so often. There was a very cavalier attitude about teen sex and teen pregnancy. This book was heartbreaking in many spots, but I liked that the characters tried to look out for each other. There was a sweetness and innocence to the characters that I enjoyed. When the two main characters, Taylor and Griggs, had sex I was very disappointed and felt Taylor was making the same mistakes her mother made--too much commitment too young. I wish she had made a better choice. Teens deserve better morals in their literature. The story was compelling, though.

On the Jellicoe Road had me quite puzzled from start to finish. I'm glad to have completed it as it allowed me to appreciate the complexity of the plot and how the story of Taylor, Raffy (Jellicoe), Chaz (Townies) and Jonah (Cadets) aligned with Hannah's story of Webb, Narnie, Fitz, Tate and Jude. When things started to make sense, did my enjoyment of this novel increase. I can't say I have it fully figured out though! I would recommend rereading the Prologue once you've finished as it helps put things into perspective. This book definitely warrants a reread in the near future!

3.5 stars.this was an interesting coming of age story. It featured Taylor, who had been abandoned by her mom at a 7-Eleven store,and who had been raised by a woman named Hannah. When Hannah up and disappears when Taylor was at school, all of Taylor's abandonment issues comes to a head. Taylor decides to go on a journey to deal to find out as much of her past, Hannah's past and her mother's past, to deal with her emotional turmoil. In the process, she grows up and the shell she built around herself cracks open.

I have many unofficial rules when it comes to rating books. One of them is: Any book that has me confused for more than half of the page count will not receive a great rating. And while this book had some emotional scenes and the end was very touching it didn't change the fact that I didn't know what the hell was going on on till 3/4 through. 5 for the last few chapters, but 3 for the whole. I don't like spending almost a whole book not knowing what the hell is going on. Taylor Markham is a teenager nearing the end of her boarding school years.  As leader in the territory wars against surrounding factions (cadets and townies) it's up to her to teach the young boarders how to survive.She was abandoned by her mother at age 11 and has since depended on Hannah, her mentor at school. But recently Hannah has gone missing without so much as a goodbye, and Taylor is starting to suspect there's information about her past that people aren't telling her.I hadn't read any Marchetta before this book, and I'm unsure if this is her typical writing style, but it was difficult for me to follow. Marchetta doesn't spell things out of you. The story changes pace, setting, and characters frequently and without warning.Without knowing much about this book beforehand, I jumped right in, and I wasn't quite sure what I found. The territory wars seemed borderline fantasy, and Marchetta leaves the objectives and what's at stake a little vague. Is this a real war? Are these kids really fighting for their lives?You're introduced to many, many characters almost immediately and some who go by multiple names. The story alternates following two similar groups of friends -- one in present day (Taylor) and one generations before. The connection between the two, and who exactly these people are, is part of the mystery.I will admit my personal experience with this book was a confused one. It's compelling and disjointed. I often had to flip back and read a page again to be sure I wasn't missing something only to discover that I hadn't missed anything at all -- Marchetta intentionally plants question after question within each chapter.You're surprisingly exposed to multiple layers within many characters despite there being very little time dedicated to them. For those of you turned off by the typical YA romance, you may want to give this one a shot. These teens face real difficulty and you, as the reader, can't help but get invested and root for them the whole way.

This book was certainly not bad and by the end I actually really liked where it ended up and had developed a fondness for pretty much all the characters by the time we got there. But the journey it took to get there was just so needlessly convoluted. I just felt the construction of this story didn't work for me. It's like it was doing everything possible to confuse me by constantly flitting between present and dreams and Hannah's story, but I don't feel like it actually added anything to the overall story by doing that. Like I still guessed all the revelations and it didn't make it more impactful by confusing me the entire time, I feel like if it was told in a less random time-jump way I could've felt these moments a lot more. There's these great emotional beats at the end that honestly didn't hit me the way I knew they should have because it took so long to get to it. Also the beginning plot of their 'house wars' or whatever was as dumb as it sounded and legit led nowhere. It felt like such ridiculous forced conflict and wasn't even well explained enough for me to care. It took itself far too seriously and I found myself eye-rolling for a lot of it and waiting for the real meat of the story to happen. I also found the main relationship and Taylor herself super grating. All of their decisions are beyond frustrating and I know they're teenagers and I know they need to grow in their arc, but I didn't really find myself routing for them for most of the book. By the end I enjoyed them enough separately that I was like, 'ok sure, fine' but again didn't hit me the way I felt it should've. Overall this book was just super weird. It's certainly different and I'm all for fresh ideas, but it just didn't do it for me at all. Not my fav, but I can see why others may have enjoyed it more.

Jellicoe Road isn't a bad book. It's fine. It was enjoyable. I (mostly) had fun reading it and both laughed and cried, which is always a good thing. But I resent TF out of all you people who gave me astronomical expectations with all your effing 5 star reviews. Honestly, how even dare you love this book and make me think I would too. Because I just never Got It.Taylor is fine (but I'm not a huge fan of unreliable narrators), and Jonah is fine (but I'm not here for him being a jerk, like when he slammed Taylor up against a wall. I don't care what she said to him). Everyone else is fine, and the story about Tate, Webb, Narnie, Jude, and Fitz was fine. But there was a LOT going on, and I was overwhelmed in a bad way by all the information and underwhelmed by the execution and pacing. Honestly, I thought the best part was the war, and that got glossed over once it became obvious there was a lot going on elsewhere.If you haven't read Jellicoe Road, don't let me scare you away from it. Obviously people love it (and again, it's NOT bad). But keep your expectations manageable for your own sake. Don't let the abundance of 5 stars get your hopes up either. Just go in regular, if you can.

I liked this book. I also didn't like it. I'm cranky because I'll need to read it again to understand it better and I don't want to read it again. I don't know how to explain it except that as the pieces started to come together, I wanted to understand how it fit, but I also lost interest. Taylor started irritating me. The whole book started irritating me. Certain books and movies do this to me. Everybody loves them, I know I'm supposed to love them, and I know along the way that I'm supposed to be surprised and heartbroken and bawl and love it and say "when I got to this part, I was blown away" and "I didn't see that coming!" And "I just loved it!" And all I feel is manipulated and cranky.

The premise of the three adolescent groups struggling to survive despite an underlying darkness of abandonment and tragedy reminded me of 'Lord of the Flies'. Marchetta is a fine writer with introspective characterisation, but at times it was difficult to follow why the characters from the three groups were so obsessed with their territorial rights and rules. Then a scene is described very effectively and Marchetta's writing skill is evident. Her experience teaching in a boarding school is also evident. But the heirarchies seemed pointless. Maybe that is the point?

3.5 overall. Honestly, I want to give the first half of the book 2 stars and the second half 4 stars. When the novel begins, Taylor is whiny and angsty and I wanted to punch her in the face, and the whole "territory war" made no sense me. Where are the adults?? What is even happening?? I was reading this book for a week, something that I normally don't do because I’m a very fast reader. And before I started I did something different as well; I’ve read a lot of reviews, most of them were pointing out to have patience because the beginning is dizzy, disjointed and with too many characters which are categorised into boarders, townies and cadets.But I didn't have that big of a problem with the beginning although I was slightly annoyed because I am very ''cautious'' with YA books – especially those that have high ratings, which this one definitely has.Because I so often switch from genre to genre I give myself a right to be a sheriff and a judge in my own bookhood. I like to swoon over something and instead of being infatuated I end up being disoriented in my disbelief. I became very harsh with books – because just reading something to read, that cannot be applied to my mouth watering yearn and long lasting love affair that I will have with books till.the.end.of.my.time.la.la.la.la. So it’s not the plot that slowed my reading down, but the sentences of this book were to blame. I instantly started liking Marchetta's way of expressing herself and there was this ironical attitude that Taylor had which attracted me further. I admire people with integrity who have an opinion. Without your opinion what are you left with that it counts? She writes in a way where you can see the end. Meaning, she tells a lot of things in one subject-verb-object-fullstop. Especially when he said: ''Go to hell.'' And she replied, ''Been there. Trust me, it's overrated.'' I can tell you it’s overrated as well, but I never thought of it in this simple way. That’s the reason why I loved this book. It was full of these short written gems that you heard before but you didn’t recognise them as life savers. But this book didn’t impress me how I wanted it. It had very strong moments and toward the end, I cried but what I’ve learned in my life is that tears are not the expression of sadness; complete retreat into yourself and blessed numbness are. Tears will help you a great deal, they wash you over and nurture you, but no, they will not tell you how one person feels. Taylor didn't cry that much, but it was heartbreaking to read how stoical she had to be, if not, she would shatter. So while I liked Taylor and her development, not just with Jonah Griggs but dealing with overwhelmingly sad beginning of her childhood – see, this is where this book lost me completely - history and present were just too separated. Her life, but just her current life was great to read about because it was senselessly sad but I was getting annoyed because everything was tied up in the end, and I wished that the whole book was like the last 50 pages. I didn’t like how clumsy antagonism between townies, cadets and boarders was described, and I sure didn’t like the entire mumble jumble that happened on the Jellicoe road twenty years ago. Not the result of it, or how people dealt with that excruciating story but how Memento and Irreversible (movies) it was written. I am not talking about how confused I felt, but how it wasn’t emotionally engaging as the present story was, which is a tough cookie because it could have been just it was entangled too much. On a higher scale, this book really deals with a lot of bad things – traumas of loss and abusiveness. And that makes me somehow indecisive because there are so many things that made me lull, that I found startling and touching, and then there were these whirls of shallowness, laziness and lightness, which I can't forgive this book.What I want to say is that Marchetta’s books are difficult to review. Yeah, I’ve written so much, but these are just words. Basic message is – read this book, in the end it will not disappoint you. Whoever you are, I guarantee you that you will find something that will be just yours because reading about happy people, where’s fun in that. Reading about broken people who found a way out, mmmmm, yes please.

Rating: 3,5 stars.I'm having a hard time rating/reviewing this book. I can’t make up my mind about it. Despite it being pitched it as a mystery and many users tagging it as a romance, it felt like neither to me. Imo this was a coming of age story about friendship and bonds that are forged at a young age and last forever.One thing’s for sure: Melina Marchetta’s writing is lyrical and beautiful and captivating. “I live on the Jellicoe Road. Where trees make canopies over-head and where you can sit at the top of them and see forever.” Now, as for the story … there are actually 2 stories being told: the ‘present’ story and the ‘past’ story, which elicited opposite reactions from me. (The connection between them was obvious to me as a reader from almost the beginning, but for the heroine from the present it takes a journey that lasts the whole book to figure out how her life is connected to those from the past.)- I wasn't much invested in the ‘present’ story, mostly because I had trouble connecting with its heroine, Taylor. Her story was sad and I felt bad for her but I didn't really feel her pain as I would have for someone I knew and cared about. I never figured out what made her tick: what was going through her head when she acted the way she acted? And what was up with her weird dreams? The love interest, Jonah, was kind of “in the shadows” and for most of the book their relationship was almost non-existing. I frankly didn't feel the Taylor/Jonah love. I liked the secondary characters Raff, Chaz, Ben and Jessa a lot more than I did the MCs, but once again, they seemed barely fleshed out. I guess what I want to say is that I felt like an outsider looking into their lives but not really being a part of it. - I also didn't buy the part of the plot about the territorial wars between Townies, Cadets and Jellicoe kids. There were a lot of threats and little action. They weren't doing anything other than saying “we are at war, don’t enter our turf” and it seemed like they didn't accomplish much. (But I must admit that the literal “shit fight” made me laugh.)+ The ‘past’ story on the other hand... WOW. Narnie, Webb, Tate, Fitz and Jude carved a path right into my heart and took permanent residence there. They made my heart ache with tremendous joy and unspeakable sadness.I cried my heart out and then cried some more. I was left feeling raw. I wanted to pull them all into a group hug and never let them go. Every tragedy they experienced I experienced as if it were my own. Their friendship, their mutual love, their bond, was all incredibly beautiful and heat-breaking. Nostalgic. Bittersweet. Melancholic. Everlasting. Memorable. And that ending! In a nutshell: two stories were told and interwoven in this book. One I was rather indifferent to; the other I was totally invested in and loved. I wish the people from the ‘past’ story had had more page time, or even had the book all to themselves and then I would surely had rated Jellicoe Road with 5 stars.Australian slang I picked up:*Gaol=jail*Pash= heavy duty kissing between teenagers/snog.

This was the perfect example of a ‘slow’ story that isn’t boring. The pacing is pretty slow, but it builds on itself and reveals information and history about the characters, their relationships, and the world. The story grows and develops and blooms. It’s a weird one - I wouldn’t think much about it when I wasn’t reading, but when I was reading it had my full attention. 
Things I Liked
:I really liked the writing style. It was very much a stream of consciousness style that I found easy to read. It was easy to connect with Taylor because we get so much of her emotions and thoughts from the writing. I liked how we were discovering information alongside her. The story pulls you with it and keeps you engaged.I really loved the flashback scenes to Narnie, Tate, Jude, Fitz, and Webb. I found the characters endearing and very lively. They had such an earnest friendship and it was great to see. (view spoiler)[I also loved that Hannah’s book was about these flashback characters we meet and that the story was her story. The story of her and her friends, it paralleled Taylor, Griggs, Santangelo and the other characters beautifully (hide spoiler)] We get so much history from them. I loved seeing how their relationship changed the townies, the cadets, and the Jellicoe school kids.I also really loved the dynamic that developed between Griggs, Taylor, and Santangelo. As the chosen leaders of the cadets, the Jellicoe school houses, and the townies respectively, it was nice to see their interactions change and evolve over the course of the story. The learn more about each other and their history and they evolve naturally. I really loved the bonding at the Prayer tree, it felt so genuine that I became completely invested in these three characters.
Things I Didn’t Like
:I didn’t really care about Raffaela at all. She felt pretty useless as a character to me. I know she has some kind of history with Santangelo that was supposed to cause drama or at least bring her into the core group, but we don’t get any information to actually make me care. The side characters in general all receive virtually no information, but that’s really ok because the story is more about the core group and their history and the history of Jellicoe road. But Raffaela is integrated as part of the core group, but I don’t think we get enough of her to establish her on her own.The serial killer side plot fell completely flat to me. There wasn’t enough information to establish is and it didn’t have much closure either. It never went anywhere, it was just brought up now and again with no history or development. It was really just unnecessary and didn’t add anything at all to the story.This was an enjoyable and engaging read, that builds and creates this hazy world of nostalgia and mystery. I really liked how the answers revealed themselves naturally and organically. The characters and the world are ethereal, while still being incredible grounded in emotion and humility.

"—Estoy aquí por ti, tú eres mi prioridad. Tu felicidad, de alguna manera jodida, está unida a la mía. A ver si se te mete en la cabezota. ¿Te gustaría que fuera de otra manera? Demonios, sí, pero no creo que pase mientras yo viva."
Empecé este libro por Melina, porque amé Finnikin of the Rock y porque quería leer algo más suyo… y no pensé, ni por un segundo, que me produciría tantas emociones al mismo tiempo y me haría sentir tan bien y tan mal simultáneamente. Me ha gustado mucho, pero también lo he odiado. Es un sentimiento difícil de explicar, pero lo intentaré.
"…la gente con tanta personalidad me asusta terriblemente. Hacen que quiera ser mejor persona, sabiendo que no me es posible."
Más de la mitad del libro me desconcertó, no entendía muy bien lo que leía y no por qué fuera un lenguaje complicado sino porque no me enteraba del porqué de nada. Necesitaba saber por qué las cosas eran como las leía pero no lo conseguía, no le encontraba sentido y me frustraba. El personaje principal me molestaba porque siempre tenía una actitud de todo me vale una mierda y constantemente estaba buscando una “razón” para alejarse de los que la querían y se preocupaban por ella porque sentía que no podía depender de nadie, la habían abandonado ya dos veces y no se creía capaz de soportar eso de nuevo. Creó una barrera entre ella y los demás, siempre aparentemente impenetrable. Me frustraba porque quería que abriera los ojos, que se diera cuenta que no estaba sola y que aunque había sufrido no todo podría ser tan malo… pero todo fue una ilusión, y más o menos cuando le quedaban unas cien páginas al libro, todo cambió. Y la entendí, sufrí por ella y con ella y me abrumó todo lo que se descubre en estas páginas. Entonces me agradó, pero no me podía olvidar de lo tedioso que fue soportarla anteriormente. "Si quiero más, tengo que ir a buscarlo, exigirlo, abrazarlo con todas mis fuerzas y tratarlo de la mejor manera de la que soy capaz."Me gustó porque Melina escribe precioso y me hizo sentir lo que leía, me hizo sufrir y me hizo lamentar que a veces la vida de unas personas tan buenas no vaya tan bien como se podría esperar. Fue tan abrumador que en ocasiones no quería continuar leyendo, porque sabía que se descubriría un hecho que me dolería saber. Todos mis no tiene sentido, es incoherente, parece más un juego que otra cosa… y demás dudas y críticas se vieron opacadas por tanto sentimiento. Mientras leía pase de pensar que se merecía una estrella por hacerme perder el tiempo a que se las merecía todas. Yo no le doy cinco por lo que dije, porque también lo odié y me hizo muy mal aunque sea una novela espectacularCreo que se merece una oportunidad porque pasa de ser absurdo e ilógico a ser bonito y esperanzador. Me molestaron muchas cosas, pero al final creo que fueron más los pros que los contras.
I liked it, but the confusing parts of the story made me less reluctant to keep continuing on. At least it wrapped up in a sweet ending.And Jonah Briggs, though.

3.5 starsThis is a tricky book to review. I haven't actually read a Melina Marchetta since Looking for Alibrandi in Highschool. I loved Looking for Alibrandi. It got me through many difficult, angsty 16 year old times. Had I read Jellicoe Road in High School, I feel I would have loved it just as much.Because the thing is - Taylor is a really great main character. She's a rough around the edges, but damaged, needy girl who is able to pull out her strength when she needs it. All she realls wants is to love and be loved. The story is centred around Taylor's search for her mentor, Hannah, who has disappeared in the middle of the night to "care for a friend". Taylor has reason to believe that isn't true and is concerned for Hannah's safety.In the middle of the search for Hannah is the "war" - the school is divided up into various factions, and they have battled for years, distributing various areas of the school to the diffrent factions based on the outcomes of strategy and negotiation. People from other factions aren't really supposed to be friends, but there is definitely some emotion going on between Taylor and Jonah Griggs (who may I add, is a bit yummy.)As well as all of these concepts, the chapters are interspersed with the manuscript that Hannah is writing about 5 friends on the Jellicoe Road. And these 5 friends are starting to feel awfully familiar to Taylor.Right so - Marchetta certainly knows how to write a believeable love story. I loved Josie & Jacob in looking for Alibrandi, and I certainly loved Taylor Markham and Jonah Griggs. There is something so raw and real about them. It isn't all sunshine and lollipops - they are both seriously flawed characters who manage to bring out the best in each other.I read the book fairly quickly, because it was certainly very readable. There were a few times when I scratched my head and flicked back a few pages because I felt I had missed something, but it all came together in the end. As far as the story goes, it was pretty good. Not amazing, but I would certainly prefer to see teenagers reading this over something like Twilight.

When I first started reading Jellicoe road, the first chapters or so I was very confused. I did not get anything, I did not like how it was written, I did not like the characters, I did not know where the characters were, who was named what and why certain things happened. But it was still quite capturing. It was a mystery. And the more you read the more you found out. I kept finding it flurry until I had read about half of the book. There I got more answers and I now knew the characters better and I understood them and that made me like them. The book still contained a whole lot of mystery and secrets. The other half of the book is the most exiting I think. You get a lot more clues, things get solved and romance becomes on of the big topics. And there I found myself totally captivated and unable to put the book down. I found the story both really lovely and sad.The romance in the book is so beautiful that it almost beats romance in other romance novels. The main character Taylor Markham is a 17 year old girl who lives at the Jellicoe boarding school. On the outside she seems very tough but underneath it all she is very fragile. She was abounded by her mother at fourteen and do not have an idea where her mother is now. The book is about looking for something you been missing and feeling empty and lost but then finding these things that makes you whole. I did not know if I really liked the book when I stated reading it cause it was just so unclear. But when I had finished it and everything made sense and I got a closure of the story I found myself loving everything about it. I recommend this book to anyone who would like a good, touching, can not put down kind of book.

Taylor is the head of her house at the Jellicoe boarding school and she’s the head of the school in the territory wars between the school, the Townies, and the Cadets. Taylor ran away from school 3 years ago when she was 14 (with one of the Cadets – Jonah Griggs) to try and find her mother who abandoned her at a 7-11 when she was just a little girl. Taylor’s been wondering about her family and her past for as long as she can remember, and this year things come to a head when her guardian, Hannah, disappears for several weeks to take care of some “personal” business, and leaves Taylor alone and frustrated. Taylor and the leaders of the Cadets and Townies become close friends, as the leaders once were back when the territory wars started. And it’s Jonah, again, who accompanies Taylor when she sets off – this time to track down Hannah – in search of the truth.This is really two stories woven together - Hannah’s story about her past, and Taylor’s story about her present. They’re remarkably similar – with young people who come to be friends and then more than friends, who invent and play a game just so they can spend more time together, and who have a shared history. In Hannah’s story, however, there’s a terrible tragedy that affects the lives of all the others and continues to have effects years later. It’s what makes Taylor’s mom turn to drugs so she can forget, what makes her abandon Taylor, what makes Hannah keep a distance from the people she loves, and what eventually brings the survivors back together again. This is all about the friendships forged and the unraveling mystery of Taylor’s and Hannah’s past. I really like Melina Marchetta’s writing, she creates realistic characters and situations and stories with depth.

Jellicoe Road Review	Jellicoe Road is a boarding school where social aspects are taken seriously and adults are not allowed to know details. Taylor Markham was abandoned at a gas station by her drug-addicted mother at age eleven. She is 17, lives in Jellicoe School, with many state wards and troubled children. She is in charge of her House of younger girls and is expected to lead an ongoing 'territory war' between the Jellicoe School kids. She battles with the 'Townies' and the Cadets. Her main source of parental guidance (Hannah) goes missing and she becomes emotionally distraught. The genre is mystery; however, the story line is more about the intense journey instead of solving unanswered questions. Within Jellicoe Road relationships are formed between the most different of people. Taylor’s house has been burnt down and in the ruins she finds the most love from the people she didn’t appreciate as much as she should have. After talking to her house mate Raffy, Taylor internally decides “to vow to keep Raffy around for the rest of (her) life.” This quote magnifies the love between friends and the safety net everyone forms with each other.Jellicoe road can be seen in many different ways, from the inside it is a competitive confusing place where trust is always at question. Although the houses negotiate for territory they know inside what is right and what belongs to whom. Often threatening each other, “Whatever is now covered up will be uncovered and every secret will be made known.” Within the Jellicoe system are people that know everything about each other yet now are in competition.

Perhaps part of my problem with this book is that I was constantly comparing it to Looking for Alibrandi, which dominated my teen years. That and the fact that I went to high school in an area where lots of the boys' schools have cadet corps, and I know what total asshats cadets can be. Really, it was only the fact that it had so many positive reviews from people I trust that kept me reading. The first hundred-odd pages was enormously confusing. I had no idea who the protagonist was, other than that her name was Taylor and that she attended a boarding school somewhere in rural New South Wales. Based on the fact that it's seven hours from Sydney, you go through Yass to get there and it's somewhere near the Murrumbidgee based on various names that crop up in the story, I'm going with somewhere around Hay, but that's just because I like to have some kind of sense of where things are set when I read Australian books. ANYWAY. It took a LONG time for the story to get going. Like, a third of the book kind of long time. Prior to that, there were ideas flying around everywhere, and overlapping stories, and I generally felt like my copy of the book was missing at least 50 pages of story and that I'd just been dumped in the middle. But I persevered, and it did get better. The overlapping stories came together beautifully, and I loved Taylor slowly discovering that not everything is the way she thinks it is. Some of the scenes were absolutely beautiful. I think it would have been a 4 star book for me if it hadn't taken so long for me to feel involved in the story. Perhaps it's one that will grow on me with rereads in the future...

The beginning of this book is so confusing, I almost abandoned it, but I'm nine chapters in now and totally hooked on the mystery of who everyone is and how they are connected...so, the mystery doesn't last too long, but by the time you've figured out who's who, the characters have become interesting, and you want to see what will happen. It's a little bit hard to characterize this book as "realistic," since it has a feeling of unreality both because the setting seems a bit implausible and the dreams are mystical, but it isn't a fantasy either. The setting is a rural boarding school (in Australia) apparently largely for troubled kids and orphans, where there is an annual battle for territory between the students of the school, the townies and the cadets from a military school that spend time camping nearby. Taylor Markham, who was abandoned by her mother years earlier, becomes the leader of the students in her last year at the school, and also is in charge of the care of all of the students in her house. Hannah, a woman who lives in an unfinished house by the river, has provided a refuge and support to Taylor since picking her up from the store where she was abandoned. But Hannah mysteriously disappears, leaving behind a sad and mysterious manuscript, just when Taylor feels she needs her most. When the cadets come, Jonah Griggs is their leader, and he and Taylor have an uncomfortable and confusing history. To further complicate the normal territorial wars, the townies' leader Santangelo, is a lifelong friend of Taylor's best friend at school, Rafaela. Everything is tied together in a tangle that is revealed gradually.

I cringe as I give this book three stars. Most of my friends who have read it loved it. Which goes to show what we all know, books don't affect all people the same. I can understand why people liked the book, but for me it was really slow in the beginning and I just wasn't getting it. I got the general idea that Taylor had been abandoned by her mother on Jellicoe Road. Hannah, the woman who found her and who has given her a home has now disappeared. Perhaps it is me but I had trouble figuring out the boarding school that Taylor is attending and just what this "war" these kids are conducting between "Townies", "Cadets" and the "Houses" was all about. I still don't really understand it. I made one error in reading this book, and this is advice for anyone who is going to read it. I did not pay enough attention to the story that Hannah had written and Taylor is reading a page or two at a time. I think I was too concerned with trying to figure out this world Taylor is living in and missed some details that later play a major part in the story. There is romance in this book between Taylor and Jonah and that part was nicely done. There is also a touch of the supernatural in Taylor's dreams when she loses consciousness. It's a mystery of sorts as this girl tries to figure out who everyone is and what part they played in her early life. It is not a bad book and I was never tempted to not finish it, but I kind of had to make myself pick it up and keep reading at times. I just never was really in it.

I glanced over the other glowing 5 star reviews and somehow I feel guilty for rating this an honest 3 stars, meaning, I did like it... but not to point of "really" liking it.Like other reviewers, I felt completely lost in the first 100 pages and wanted to give up at several points, but other reader's assertions that it would all click into place pushed me to finish the book. Yes, it does get better.The main problem is I couldn't picture what the setting and some characters looked like. It's my personal thing that I often struggle with, but some aspects never clicked. For example, the fact that there would be territory wars between the Cadets/Townies/Jellicoe students seemed unbelievable to me. And that all this would go unnoticed by the adults. It was easy to lose track of the characters like Anson Choi, Ben Cassidy, Mullet Brothers.... it seemed the only thing that defined them was their name and I found myself having to flip back and re-read pages multiple times just to be able to get a gist of what was going on. This jumbled-ness really irritated me in the beginning, especially with the pages of Hannah's story. Again, I emphasise my experience of the novel is shaped by my personal reading style - perhaps a difficulty in fully immersing myself into the story.Gripes over, I really did like the story. Very clever, well written and with strong endearing main characters that bind you to them. Examples of this are Taylor and Griggs. Perhaps this is one of those novels I have to read more than once to fully appreciate that. Will update review then.

Sigh. When a book wins an award and the majority of reviewers gush about it, I feel like I should pay attention.The last half of the book almost redeems the first half. Almost. But the first half was so confusing that the payoffs in the second half fell flat. I wanted to go back to the early part and reread it (hard to do on a kindle) and decided not to. I shouldn't have to work that hard to figure things out.The tone is realistic; I like that. The first person narration seems right. But the setting was... odd to say the least. They're in a boarding school but there's no actual school going on. Where are the teachers? Why are there territory wars with cadets and townies? (The turf wars had little or nothing to do with the meat of the story - why Taylor, the narrator, was abandoned as a child.) And why was every single main character broken? And why did the few adults in the book - all connected to the narrator by blood or by history - have to keep the secrets about the narrator's parents? I'm equivocating with a two star review. Frankly I'm growing weary of the star system. I would like to dispense with these stars because they say nothing really. Was it a quality book? Maybe. So many reviewers say it is the BEST book they EVER read. Okay, I believe them. It didn't do much for me, and if it hadn't been for their urging to read it to the very end, I might have stopped after 100 pages.

Jellicoe Road, written by Melina Marchetta, has a very captivating plot that will have your eyes glued to the book for hours, but the book does have its confusing areas. I did not really adore the main character, Taylor Markham, because I noticed throughout the book that she is not a very nice and joyful person to be around. This is because there were spots in the book where she was cruel to kids and through her actions, you could tell that she is a depressed and anxiety - prone girl. For example, Taylor was rudely sarcastic to Hannah, her mentor and guardian, "I don't have wings, Hannah" (Marchetta 21). It is not her fault that she is that way because her mom ditched her when she was only 11, and she only has one recollection of her father due to him dying when she was really young. I also feel that the author should have put more thought into the character development of Taylor so that readers can see how Taylor progresses throughout the book, since she was a major part of the book. I did especially like the territory war between the Townies and the Cadets. I thought this war brought a lot of captivation to the readers, since it is a subject that we have never experienced in other books. One thing that happened during the territory war: "On the other side of the room of the Darling girls are surrounded by Cadets while the girls from Hastings House look on in total envy" (Marchetta 294).

This is one of those books that you have to finish before you can form a complete opinion about it. In the beginning I found it very choppy and hard to follow. All of the characters felt disconnected, the narrator Taylor was a void for me - I couldn't figure out who she was and where she was coming from. As the story progresses the pieces start falling into place and everything starts making sense. While I can conceptually appreciate how the author structured the book to embody the experience and mindset of its narrator, I don't know if it is completely successful in practice. It definitely requires a measure of patience and perseverance on the part of the reader to stick with it long enough to be given sufficient information to start caring about the characters. I also found the "story" that is set in italic and interwoven with narrative a bit disorienting until it is made clear that is Hannah's story that Taylor is reading. While some of the mysteries took a while to completely untangle, I found that I was able to discern the true identities of most of the characters a long while before the revelations within the book. Even so, the way Taylor internalizes it manages to give it extra weight and intensity.By the end, I found that the story had exceeded my initial expectations. It is a transformative experience, both for the characters and the reader.

While there were some wonderful parts in Jellicoe Road,, in the end, it just fell short for me. I think if I had read this upon its release, I’d have enjoyed it more. Too many authors that have mimicked this format now, and it’s not as fresh as it once was. Griggs was the highlight of the book. I love a strong, steady hero, and he was he was solemn to boot. There was no reading between the lines with this guy; you knew what he wanted you to know. Unfortunately, I wasn’t a fan of Taylor. It was hard for me to tell what her motivations were, and there was a point where she crossed the line for me. She was never able to come back from that. The parallel story was much more interesting than the one being told in its entirety, and I thought that was detrimental to the overall book. The reason some of the secrets were kept from Taylor felt flimsy to me. It was predictable, and while there were some emotional parts, I was never able to fully connect with anyone in the book. I did, however, love Raffy and Santangelo’s cat and mouse game, and I wish we’d seen more of them. Simon also tugged at my heart strings, and I’d have loved there to be some sort of resolution there. I guess, overall, I was looking for more things to be tied up.This review was originally posted at Badass Book Reviews.

I rarely give out five stars, that is reserved for books that really, really catch me. Books that make me look at the world differently or that just speak to me on some level I wasn't expecting. Jellicoe Road did all three. This is a beautiful, haunting book and I know the characters will remain with me for a long time. The characters are what make this book shine and they are so well done! Marchetta creates characters that leap from the page and feel like friends you might have known in school. The descriptions are beautiful and lyrical. The pace is at times fast, at times leisurely and slow, but always moving forward with a sort of inevitability that does not feel forced or contrived. Taylor Markham is trying to unravel the secrets in her past, to find where her guardian has disappeared to. At the same time, the tale of five friends who met on the Jellicoe Road more than 20 years before unfolds along side Taylor's. As the two stories overlap and weave together the narratives combine into one remarkable, tragic and redemptive story that feels true and deep. This is definitely going on my permanent book shelf and will be read again.

For me it was an OK read. Review: This story is one that tells 2 stories into one. It slowly unravels the mystery of a group of 5 friends who come together after a terrible accident on Jellicoe Road.It tells a tragic story of love and loss. I loved how strong Taylor was while she was trying to dig into her mother and fathers past. Even Griggs, who is the leader of the Cadet with his drill sergeant attitude, has a compassionate side that he shares with Taylor. That compassion is what helps Taylor as she goes in search to find her mother. Slowly you see how their love grows even at times when you think their relationship is over!At times I felt very confused on which characters story I was reading about. I feel that if I were to read it a second time I would understand in better detail the past of the characters more.Overall I thought that it was a good story. I don't think this would be a book I would buy from the bookstore though. I would have rather got it from the library or borrowed it from someone. I would still recommend this novel to anyone. It was a good story of friends, family, love, and loss.

First of all, this book is long. Like, really long. I listened to the audio book on 1.5x speed and I still feel like it took me just forever to finish it. I liked the flow of the story, and I appreciate any book where the author tries to make it more character than plot driven, because I'm sure that's very challenging. That being said, I found it to be relatively predictable for the most part (some aspects were surprising, but the majority of it went exactly as I expected), I didn't understand the point of the serial killer side plot, and the whole territory war thing seemed contrived. My biggest complaint though was the Jellicoe school. All of this crap is going on, kids actually getting kidnapped or physically injured in a fake war, and the teachers are conspicuously absent. Seriously, these are the WORST teachers in the world. The only person that even semi cares about these kids is Hannah, and she's gone for half the book. I just felt like this egregiously long book would have been half the length with some educator intervention. Not a bad read, but not my favorite.

I loved this unreservedly when I read it years ago, even in my extreme confusion. I didn't remember much of the story before rereading, but things came back to me and I worked out everything before it happened. I don't know if that was because I remembered it or if things were glaringly obvious. It felt a lot more like the latter.I was so disappointed that I didn't love it this time round. Mostly I was bored to sleep or rolling my eyes with incredulity. If Hannah was gone for six weeks, where were all the teachers or even lessons in this school for delinquents and derelicts. Was no-classes their all new method for teaching? Leaving the kids to play war games was how education happened these days?I totally regret rereading. I ruined my happy memories of how much I loved life and death on the Jellicoe Road."I'm very disturbed to find out the leader of the Townies has a soul."

Read for the 2015 Book Genre Challenge|Contemporary3.5 I wish i had enjoyed this book more, believe me, i do. And even though i could notice the sadness of it, i couldn't get too attached to the story or characters - I mean, i'm in love with Ben but.. -. I'm not sure what happened. The first fifty pages were too confusing -english not being my mother language probably didn't help- but then i got it and could read it smoothly - which hasn't been happening in a while so points for that- but as the story kept going i would still ask myself why everyone loved it so much. That being said, i still have high hopes for the rest of Melina Marchetta's books, it's not as if i didn't enjoy this book after all. It did make me feel, but i guess it's been such a weird year of reading that books are not affecting me as much.

hmmmm..... this is one of those books wherein you really really liked it or don't like it at all. its either you give it a 5 star rating or 1 star rating and not in between. reading this book i had a lot of expectations but sad to say that i only liked this book during the last few chapters of it. it was rather slow and boring 75% read for me and i'm having a hard time just getting into it. though i would say that the remaining 25% of it, i really like. and another thing i liked about it: griggs! i wouldnt say he's hot (though he is, in his own "i'm not aware i'm hot" way) but as taylor described him: he is one romantic guy having done what he has done for taylor and for her to come in terms with herself and her being. having said this, it's still worth the read if you want to be touched in a heart warming way.

This is purely a spoiler review. I was reading this and it had so many secrets that I had to look at snippets of other peoples reviews just to get some insight on what was going on, who the characters were and what was going on, so if you don't want to know the secrets look away CharactersTaylor Lily Markmen Jonah Griggs - her love interest, cadet leaderRaffeala/Raffy - her bffChaz Santangelo - Townie LeaderJessa -(view spoiler)[Fitz daughter (hide spoiler)]Tate - (view spoiler)[Tate Markman, Taylors mother, is dying of cancer (hide spoiler)]Webb - (view spoiler)[Xavier Webster Schroeder, Taylors father (hide spoiler)]Narnie - Webbs sister (view spoiler)[is really Hannah. Taylors Aunt (hide spoiler)]The Brigader -(view spoiler)[Jude Scanlon (hide spoiler)]The Hermit -(view spoiler)[Fitz (hide spoiler)]Hope that helps people.

This one is hard for me to review. I'm very conflicted on what to rate this book. It took me about 150 pages before I even started to pull together what was happening. It almost felt like I had started reading the second book in a series without reading the first one to understand what in the world was going on. I was so lost for the first 150 pages I was very close to giving up on reading it.Another big thing I didn't like was the language. This book is classified as a Young Adult book, but I wouldn't recommend it to any of the young people I know who are currently reading this level of books. The f-word was used so many times I lost count. Also there is some sex in the book (although not overly graphic).I did, in the end, enjoy the story. It all finally makes sense, but the way it was written makes me rate it 3 stars.

I enjoy stories woven together - multiple threads that seem unrelated tied back into a lovely pattern. This book is more like a Rauschenberg painting - at first there is a sense of chaos, of story lines that you know MUST be related (they are in the same book after all) but its not tidy, like a tapestry where the picture starts to become clearer as its woven. The longer you look at a Rauschenberg painting, though, the more you can see pattern and even a cohesive theme. There are themes of abandonment, mixed with love and hope, of learning about the frailties of one's parents (who are human and have a past that does not include you), of discovering a history you belong to. My favorite idea what put into two statements: "Belong. Longing to be."

Sorry JB, but this book DID NOT deserve to win the Printz. Not when it was up against Tender Morsels, Octavian Nothing: Kingdom on the Waves, and The Disreptuable History of Frankie Landau-Banks (which should have won instead). Jellicoe Road is beautifully written, and the characters are well-drawn and full of life, BUT it was full of way too many realistic teen fiction cliches (abandoned teens, boarding school skirmishes, ultimate romance between bitter rivals, and so on). Also, the connections between the past and present narratives become apparent pretty early on, and then the plot becomes rather predictable. It was a good book, and I don't regret reading it, but it didn't blow me away like Frankie Landau-Banks did.

This was an intriguing story, with the past and present wound together like the fibers in a rope. The characters were complex and sometimes unfathomable, the setting almost otherworldly.That being said, were I an editor, I would have mercilessly cut a hundred pages from this book. I was mostly bored until page 218, and it was only because this is my friend Wendy's favorite book that I slogged through. At that page, I suddenly figured out the entire story. The pace of the book picked up and held my attention, for the most part, until the end. I admit that I am not a fan of realistic fiction and I like Marchetta's fantasy books much more.

I would actually give this a 3.5, I think. The book is a bit hard to follow at first as a host of characters and plot points are introduced in series of somewhat cryptic context clues...which slowly gain more clarity over the course of the story. I did start to figure out some twists early on, so there were little surprises, here, but the book has a lot going for it. The story centers on Taylor Markham, who, over the course of the summer faces a series of crises and revelations that answer her questions about who she is, who she came from, and where she is going. I found the characters to be honest, the story to be interesting, emotional, and ultimately pretty satisfying.

The only reason I am not giving this book 5 stars is because I honestly felt like giving up in the beginning. I couldn't keep up with the story at first, and it seemed like it would never get interesting. I stuck it out because all the reviews said that if you feel like giving up, wait until at least a hundred pages in. After trudging through the beginning of the book, and reaching that hundred page mark, it all started coming together. I'm really glad I didn't give up on this book. It was wonderful. So, anyone who is just starting this book and wanting to give it up, don't do it. It's worth the read.

I hated this book at first. Too much information, new characters, confusing, disorienting information. I thought it was one of those dystopia novels at first and I kept thinking how misleading the blurb from the goodreads description was. I kept reading though and didn't enjoy it much until I got about halfway through and then I could see all the pieces falling together and it ended strong enough for me to raise my star-rating from a two to a three. Parts were really well-written and beautiful; while others just weren't. Some characters were more likeable than others. I could see teenagers liking this a lot.

It's most certainly me... because the ending of On the Jellicoe Road was totally magical and perfect, and yes, I would agree that the ending made the rest of the book worth it. That being said, the rest of the book - was so very serious and bleak and just, for that reason alone, not more than 3 stars for me. Also, the first 150+ pages of confusion made me impatient. The multiple storylines, the characters that I couldn't tell apart... it does all become clear at the end of it all, but that was a lot of bewildered time that I really think could have been made somewhat less bewildering.But, I can see why so many others loved it. I almost even had a tear or two happening.

I went in only knowing the title, so a lot of the first 25% was spent thinking "how serious is this situation?" "is this post-apocalyptic?" "is this supernatural?" "where even are they" and so on. Kind of nifty slowly discovering what the deal is via scattered context clues sans any preconception of what the book is about... What I do think I'd say the book is perhaps about is that feeling of lacking control over your life and the information you do or do not possess about yourself and others, and the strugs that result. That's something I personally identify with, at least!vague review is vague

This was a very interesting story and, while confusing in the beginning, comes together quite nicely in the end. I really liked some of the plot devices use to make these connections and drive the story, and I appreciated getting to gain a gradual understanding rather than having everything laid out for me in the beginning. The characters are well-fleshed out and engaging. What took this book from a 4-star to a 3-star review for me was the language and the few sexual situations - This is not a clean read, and that is something I look for. Just a heads up for others in the same boat.

I wanted to like this book more than I did, partly because I really liked the other two Melina Marchetta's books I'd read (Looking For Alibrandi and Saving Francesca) and partly because there are so many 5 star reviews on Goodreads for this one. Overall it was a good story but it was really mysterious and had two stories being told at once and to be honest, I was pretty confused through most of it trying to figure out who was who and how they were connected.It did all come together in the end (mostly), but all the guessing took away a lot of the enjoyment of the story for me.

Ok, so....mad props to the YA readers who could understand what the hell was even going on for the first 1/3 of the book. I was completely lost. Couldn't figure out the narration or the italics and holy cats there were a lot of similar names to try to get straight. I keep wondering if I'm missing something major since all the reviews I've ever seen of this book are just glowing. My mind has been elsewhere this week, so maybe if deserves a second chance. Maybe. I shouldn't have to TRY to enjoy a book though right? Ugh.

The first half of this book is super confusing. I had no idea wtf was going on most of the time and I almost gave up on it. Only the fact that everyone loved it kept me reading. I loved Jonah and the trip to the city. I loved that the tunnel was real. And I loved the maniacal way the story was told, once I understood where it was going. There's just something about it that I didn't love, something that everyone else found in the story that I didn't. Maybe after I think about it and digest, I'll change my rating.

There's something that resonates with me in this story. The hopes and fears that Taylor feels toward the people in her life are things I think most people can identify with and understand. Plus, on a less serious note anything that makes me cry my own tears has to get at least 3-stars. And not to be a Debbie Downer, but sometimes the unnecessarily "inscrutable, secretive, reticent, evasive, furtive" characters masquerading around under the pretense of something mysterioso wasn't impressive.

The journey through this book was a long and twisted road. Beginning with confusion and frustration. I had heard that this book was so amazing, and for the first 100 pages or so, I was completely and utterly confused. However, after persisting through the book, slowly I began to get more and more invested in the story and understood the beautifully written characters. It wasn't until the end, after all the pieces fell into place that I could fully appreciate this amazing book.

I think that my main problem with this book is that it took 200 pages for the story to start coming together. For the first half, it was just confusing. You didn't have enough information yet, & therefore the story dragged. Other than that, it was an interesting story. Nothing too exciting, but with an ending that really tied up all loose ends.

This book was a challenge, but worth a read.Surreal, and yet sometimes all too close.A well-drawn cast of characters who are all linked to one another in ways they never could have imagined and whose lives must invariably touch.There are many, many excellent reviews already out there on this book, so I am not going to try for a synopsis here.

I went through a lot of different feelings while reading this book; beginning with confusion. Once I thought I had a grip on what was going on I didn't really care but then I become consumed with needing to know what had happened in the past in.Too much teenage romance and angst for me but for lovers of YA I can imagine this being a real treat. It's beautifully written and draws you in.

This book was kind of confusing in the beginning since it wasn't in chronological order and followed different characters, but when it all came together towards the end, I couldn't stop reading it! It had to deal with friendship, love, and all the craziness that deals with our fallen nature.

This book has interesting characters and a nicely grim moodiness but much of the story was frustrating. The ending ties it up and redeems it but patience through the first half may be required by many readers.
It's a 3.5 actually. :D
Actual rating=3.5
Al fin lo terminé!!!
By the end of this book I was really engrossed, but it took awhile. The interaction between the two stories was intriguing.
It was good but very confusing specially at first
